DURING THE HALFTIME TAP AT the Hopkins-Dickenson football game, eleven men received the palm from Omicron Delta Kappa, national honorary service

- Council Code Ratified
By Undergrad Body
by CLEAVELAND MILLER

The student body overwhelmingly passed the Constitutional Referendum by a vote of 517 to 101 in balloting
which took place last Monday and Tuesday.
President Lew Sank of the'Student Council said of
the Referendum's passing, "I am very pleased at the
results of the Constitutional Referendum. Now the Student
Council will be able to concentrate its efforts on behalf
of the student body in an efficient and effective manner.
I was especially pleased at the interest shown by upperclassmen, and hope that it indicates their support for the
Council's projects."
Sank continued, "With the new freshmen council representatives as well as the Chairman of the Honor Coinrnission, the President of the Interfraternity Board, the
President of the Dormitory Students Representative Council and the Chairman of the Students Activities Commission, the council will have a greater representation."

ODK To Initiate
Weekend Plans
This Afternoon
Class Day activities, beginning
at 1:30 p.m. today, will open
Omicron Delta Kappa's Fall
Weekend, according to Weekend
Chairman Roger Kane.
This year's Fall Weekend program will include: interclass athletic contests, a pep rally for the
Western Maryland • Football
Game, a jazz concert tonight and
a Car Caravan to the Western
Maryland game tomorrow.

under the sponsorship of the

TopPost To Simonsen
By Two Vote Margin
by OZ GARCIA

A two vote margin was all that separated Presidentelect Rod Simonsen from runner-up Warren Donahue,
as 333 freshmen, 83% of the class, cast their ballots for
class officers Monday and Tuesday.
Simonsen pollee 73 votes, approximately 21% of the
ballots'cast. Donahue was two votes behind, followed by
John Corcoran, 57; Ed Dudley, 52; Allan Wagner, 43;
Arnie Yalem, 21; and Marc Williams, 10.
Danny Zelman was elected vice president, polling 122
votes, followed by Larry Becker with 73 votes and Allan
Land with 66.
Another election decided by a' few votes was that
for Treasurer, in which Malcolm Kitt with 60 votes edged
out Stuart Hanlein by one vote, Jim Grossman by three,
and Jules Wellen by four.
The office of secertary was no problem for Stan
Handmaker, who with 93 votes polled 40 more than the
next candidate, Bob Bruening.

Of 14 candidates for the three
student council positions, two
foreign students were elected—
Rolf Bessin of Venezuela, and
Khann Kim Huyah of Viet-Nam.
Huyah polled the largest number of votes in the election with
245. The third representative
chosen was Boland McCamy, who
had a margin of 102 votes, 188 to
86, over Bill DeVoe who was
fourth.
The Also-Rans
Other vice-presidential candidates were Gilbert Malone, who
polled 41 votes, and Ronald
Spunar, who netted thirteen
votes. James Robinson and Ed
Smith ran for treasurer, and got
42 and 36 votes, respectively.
Wally Orlinski, with 48 votes.
and Arnie Kopleman, with 37.
led Bob Baker, 35 votes, and Art
Cheslock and David Cordish,
both of whom got 24 votes, in the
race for secretary.
Nine other candidates for Student Council were Pete Nickles.
66 votes; Al Powdermaker, 59
votes; Cleveland Miller, 57 votes;
Oz Garcia, 54 votes; Dick McCarty, 37 votes; Phil Medenbach,
33votes; Mike Borshay, 27 votes;
Jerry Cohen, 23 votes; and Bill
Harvey, eleven votes.
A total of forty-one freshmen
ran for office. This is approximately ten per cent of the total
class membership.

Gallagher, president of the

Pigskin Hop, to be held in the
gym from nine until one o'clock.
"The drinking ban should have
no effect, as the dance is oncampus." He added, "We hope
everyone will try to conduct him-

Registrar's Office
Announces Book
On JHU Courses
by STU HANDWERGER
The Registrar's Office recently
announced the printing of a
book entitled The Hopkins Undergraduate in the Faculty of
Philosophy.
Prepared under the co-authorship of Registrar Irene Davis and
Benjamin Ring, the book is an
eighty-year.survey of undergraduate instruction in the liberal
arts school.
Although copies of the book
will be distributed to the members of the faculty and to the
main reading room in the Gilman Library, no wide distribution
is planned, said Miss Davis, since
the book is of "little interest to
prospective students or the general public."
The two important facts for
the undergraduate to realize
about the book, according to Miss
Davis, are that there has always
been an undergraduate program
at the University, and that the
faculty has never ceased to plan
for undergraduate courses.

The H-Club has invited 25
members of the University faculty and administration to be pres-ent—a fact which should be a
stabilizing influence, said Gallagher.
Ches Kellum and his orchestra
will provide the music for the
affair, which will take place
among blue and black crepe paper
in a football motif. Admission is
$2.25.
"The Pigskin Hop is one of the
big dances of the fall season,"
Don Gallagher said, "and should
be one of the best." It is the
final event of the ODK weekend.
Among its other activities, the
H-Club features the annual Starlighter Dance each spring, and
also plans to hold a banquet for
senior high school athletes with
high scholastic averages.
It has also initiated a new
membership system, whereby a
letter-winner is put on a prospective membership list, and
elected only after further athletic participation or interest.

ETC Announces
Teachers' Exam
For ,Feburary
The National Teacher -Examinations, prepared and administered annually by Educational
Testing Service, will be given at
200 testing centers throughout
the United States on Saturday,
February 9, 1957, including
Goucher College in Towson and
Western Maryland College in
Westminster, it was reported bY
the Registrar's office.
At the one-day testing session, a candidate may take the
Common Examinations, which
include tests in Professional Information, General Culture, English Expression, and Non-verbal
Reasoning: and one or two of
eleven Optional Examinations designed to demonstrate mastery
of subject matter to be taught.

Official Ring For J.H.U.

John C. Nettleton expects to receive his B.S.in chemical engineering from Villanova University in June 1957. He has served as president of the student chapter of A.I.Ch.E., and as secretary of Phi
Kappa Phi fraternity. John is now wondering about the pros and
cons of advanced study in his field.

"OFFICIAL" Johns Hopkins "Blazer"—now being
featured at

Robert J. BuCh, M.S., Ch.E., came

to the Engineering Development Section of Du Pont's Grasselli Research Division from
the University of Louisville four years ago. Since then, he has
engaged in many kinds of chemical engineering work,from pilotplant operation to evaluation of the potential of proposed research programs. Within the last year, Bob has taken the responsibility of procuring B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. technical graduates in all phases of chemistry and chemical engineering for the
Grasselli Research Division.

AN advanced degree would undoubtedly have a favorable
M effect in technical work, John, but let me enlarge on
that just a little. In your own field (and mine, too) a
higher degree is considered to be evidence of ability in
carrying out original research. It is therefore helpful in
obtaining work in research and development, where that
skill is definitely important. You might say that it gives a
man a head start in proving his ability in those areas.
It's less important in some other areas, though. For
example, in production or sales work ability for handling
human relationships is just as important for advancement
as technical competence. If an engineer is sold on production" work or sales, a graduate degree in marketing
or business administration might be more helpful to him
than advanced technical training in getting started.

But I've noticed this at Du Pont. Once-a man lands a
job in his chosen field and actually begins to work, his
subsequent advancement depends more on demonstrated
ability than on college degrees. That's true throughout
the entire company—in scientific work, administration,
or what not.
So an advanced degree is not a royal road to anything
at Du Pont, John. But when coupled with proven abilities, it is unquestionably helpful to a man in research and
development work. It often gets him off to a faster start.
Are you Interested In research work?

About 2,000 Du Pont scientists are currently engaged in
research, aided by some 3,500 other employees. Laboratory
facilities of the highest quality are available at the Du Pont
Experimental Station near Wilmington, and elsewhere
throughout the country. Information about research at
Du Pont is given in "Du Pont Research." Write for your

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 16, 1956

The Petrified Forest'
Next 'Stormer Show
The Barnstormers will present
Robert E. Sherwood's "The Petrified Forest" in Shriver Hall, December 7 and 8 at 8:30 p.m. under
the direction of Lester Wolf.
Jerry Le Roux will star. as
Alan Squier, while John Gartland
Will co-star as Duke Montec and
Gloria Completon as Gabby Maple. George Edmonds will appear
as Boze Hartzlinger and Dave
Hotchberg as Gramp Maple:
Wolf will be assisted by Dave
Hotchberg, vice president of the
Barnstormers, as assistant director, and by Dave Scribner, production manager of the Barnstormers, as technical director.
A December 6 dress rehearsal
in Shriver at 8:30 will be open
to all Hopkins students. Admission for the main performances
and the dress rehearsal is free.

According to Wolf, the story
is built around "an incident in a
roadside cafe, and involves escaped,criminals and many other
human interest characters."
John Katz, Dick Danziger,
Larry Marxer, Mike Dale and
Nan Robinson take subordinate
parts, while Stuart Hanlein, Joe
Rivkin, Mike Reisman, Warren
Donahue and Ernest Boatman
will also appear, as will Walter
Darrow and Gene Coakley.
Ten freshmen will be trying out
for the Barnstormers by participating in the production, while
six regular Barnstormers members will also act.

Phi Ep's Capture
Scholarship Cup;
To 5.4 Average
Phi Epsilon Pi will receive the
1955-56 Scholarship Cup, awarded yearly to the fraternity whose
Members compiled the highest
scholastic averages in the Hopkins Greek-letter societies, according to Bill Kolomaznik, IFB
President.
Phi Ep's 55 members and
Pledges posted the highest average, 5.439. (Averages are based
on the numerical equivalents of
II-10, A-8, B-6, C-4, D-0, and
P-0.)
As far as individual scores go,
Herb Belgrad, of'Phi Epsilon Pi,
led fraternity men majoring in
Arts and Sciences with an average of 8.929; George Vlases, of
Alpha Tau Omega, led Engineering with 8.444; and Christopher
Luneski, of Sigma Phi Epsilon,
led Business with 8.067.
Other fraternity averages were
Alpha Epsilon Pi, 5.056; Sigma
Phi Epsilon, 4.955; Phi Sigma
Delta, 4.921; Alpha Tau Omega,
4.780; Kappa Alpha, 4.710; Beta
Theta Pi, 4.675; Alpha Delta Phi,
4.499; Phi Kappa Psi, 4.261; Delta
Upsilon, 4.246; Phi Gamma Delta,
4.245; Delta Phi, 4.068. The all
Men's average for the undergraduate schools is 4.869.

G-oucher Voices
Join With JHU
hi Yule Concert
The combined glee clubs of
Goucher College and Johns Hopkins and the University orchestra will present a program of
Bach, Schubert, and Buxtehude
in the annual Christmas concert
at Shriver Hall, Sunday evening,
December 2.
The program, untler the direction of Hugo Weisgall of Hopkins,'
will include the glee clubs performing Mass in A Flat by Schubert and Magnificat Anima Mea
by Buxtehude. The University orchestra will perform Overture by
Bach at the concert, which will be
open to the public at no charge.

WIHU To Initiate Show,‘
Command Performance 9
"Command Performance," a
two hour radio show, will be
initiated at 3 p.m. this Sunday
by campus radio station WJHU.
"A completely new idea in radio entertainment, COMMAND
PERFORMANCE will gather
from all areas of interest, learning and communications ,stories,
facts and music presented in a
way to provide the ultimate in
listening pleasure for the Hopkins Student," according to station manager Frank Zampiello.
The first performance will be
highlighted by an hour piano
recital by Dick Kapp, which was
taped from the grand piano in
Shriver Hall. A tribute ,to the

football team will be given in
the form of a documentary,
"Hopkins Football '56," telescoping the "preparation, activities
and the thrills of this year's Pigskin Season." The show will be
highlighted by the original recording of, Orson Welles' "War
of the Worlds."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 16, 1956

Anthropoligist Straus Asks
'Is Man Overspecialized?'
"Will he (Man) go the way of
those other overspecialized and
now extinct animals whose remains populate the various strata
of the geological record?" challenged Dr. William L. Straus, Jr.,
Professor of physical anthropology, concluding this year's
first University Lecture held
Wednesday.
In this age of nuclear fission
it remains to be seen whether
Man will make use of his unique
cerebral endowment to retain and
further expand his inheritance,
particularly by developing his
societal relations to the point of
living in peace and harmony with
other members of his own species.
•
"On the other hand, our so-

What's doing...atPrattd WhitneyAiwa

called "most advanced" current
cultures exhibit such disquieting
features as over-mechanization,
robotis, and anti-intellectuallism, worship of mediocrity, and
breakdown of many fundamental
societal relationships. If these
features really indicate as some
people suspect, that certain parts
of Man's brain have become overspecialized at the expense of the
rest of his brain and the rest of
his body, will he go the .way of
those other overspecialized and
now extinct animals whose remains populate the various strata
of the geological record? The
challenge is his to meet and
conquer.
Dr. Straus developed evolution
as it related to man from the
stage when life on earth was
totally acquatic up to the present
stage. Commenting on Aristotle's
definition of man as "the rational animal", Straus said, "As for
rationality, the less said the better, for true rationality probably
was not a property of all the men
that have lived across the span
of geological time—nor, indeed,
sadly, of all present day Men,
despite their appellation, Homo
Sapiens, or 'wise man', an appellation conceived by their own
vanity."
He said that man's brain,
"Especially its highly developed
'association' or 'ideational' areas
—represents the greatest and
actually the only real peculiarity
of Man." He added that although
the hand was critical in the deevlopment of man, it was not the
all-important factor. "There is
not a single primary movement
that can be made by the human
hand that cannot be made by the
hand of an Old World monkey.
The 'ideational' or 'conceptual'
areas of the monkey's brain,
however, are but poorly developed
when compared with these areas
of the human brain. Thus the
monkey does not have the ideas
necessary to synthesize the primary manual movements into
the intricate series of coordinated movements required in such
activity as tool-making or the
like; nor does the monkey exhibit
any great degree of foresight."

Ambitious young engineering graduates today
want to be in two places at the same time. They
want to be employed as quickly as possible, working daily at a/job that offers promise of a rewarding career. They also want to be in the classroom,
pursuing advanced studies they know to be so
essential to real professional achievement.
Recognizing the many significant benefits to be
gained by that two-fold ambition — benefits that
accrue both to the individuals, personally, and
to the company employing them — Pratt & Whitney Aircraft has developed an extensive graduate
fellowship program. Within easy commuting distance of P & W A facilities, working arrangements
have been established - with graduate schools at
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, University of

Connecticut, Trinity College, Yale University,
Northeastern University and New York University. Similar arrangements with several other universities are pending final approval.
At each school, the qualified Pratt & Whitney
Aircraft employee is able to take courses — within
specified areas — leading to a Master's degree.
A tuition-refund plan makes it possible for successful degree candidates to obtain this advanced education tuition-free.
In this era of advancing technology, the world's
foremost designer and builder of aircraft engines
has taken a far-reaching step to assure its engineers and scientists of the opportunity for personal growth ... growth that is so beneficial to
employee and company alike.

Frosh Gridders Post Fourth Win
To Close Season Undefeated
By HAL STOLLER
Led by Quarterback Oz Gakcia
and end Bob Brannon, the freshman football team scored its
fourth straight victory and climaxed an undefeated season by
downing Western Maryland 27-6
last Friday.
The fledgling Jays tallied in
the first quarter on a 19 yard
Pass from Garcia to Brannon.
Rod Simonsen added the extra
Point to make it 7 to 1'. Hopkins
tallied twice in the second period, on a quarterback sneak by
Garcia, and then with time running out, Garcia heaved .a 37
Yard pass to Brannon who went
all the way for the touchdown.
This made the score at halftime,
Hopkins 20, Western Maryland 0.
Garcia Scores
Garcia scored again in t h e
third quarter as he scampered
60 yards for Hopkins' final TD.
Simonsen again added the extra point. The defensive line play
of ends Bob Brannon, and Paul
Grim, Tackles; Marc Williams
and Paul Winegrad, Guards;
Francis Daley, John Corcoran,
and John Archer, and center
Maberon Meadows, subbing for
the injured Ray Lanzi, held the
W. Md. offense in check until
the last few minutes of the game,
When they scored on a, quarterback sneak, making the final

score, Hopkins
Maryland 6.

26,

Western

Said Coach Scott, "It was an
entire team victory, and I am
especially pleased, since this is
my first undefeated football team
I've had since I've been here."
Tackle Paul Winegrad presented Coach Major Tracy Caine
with the game football in appreciation of his work. Major
Caine has been frosh line coach
and will be leaving for Germany
in the early spring on active
duty.

Frosh Statistics
On the overall season, Simonsen, Phebus, and Garcia led the
rushing with averages of 7.1, 5.4,
and 4.6 yards per carry. Garcia
passed for 7 touchdowns out of
the 15 scored, and Simonsen
booted 11 out of 15 extra points.
Russ Martin.son averaged 38.2
yards per punt, and Simonsen
and Brannon led the team's scoring with 41 and 30 points each,
followed by Phebus and Garcia
with 12 and Martinson with 6
points.

Registrar's Office
Announces Book
On JHU Courses
by STU HANDWERGER
The Registrar's Office recently
announced the printing of a
book entitled The Hopkins Undergraduate in the Faculty of
Philosophy.
Prepared under the co-authorship of Registrar Irene Davis and
Benjamin Ring, the book is an
eighty-year.survey of undergraduate instruction in the liberal
arts school.
Although copies of the book
will be distributed to the members of the faculty and to the
main reading room in the Gilman Library, no wide distribution
is planned, said Miss Davis, since
the book is of "little interest to
prospective students or the general public."
The two important facts for
the undergraduate to realize
about the book, according to Miss
Davis, are that there has always
been an undergraduate program
at the University, and that the
faculty has never ceased to plan
for undergraduate courses.

will provide the music for the

big dances of the fall season,"

be one of the best." It is the

Among its other activities, the
H-Club features the annual Starlighter Dance each spring, and
also plans to hold a banquet for

letter-winner is put on a prospective membership list, and
elected only after further athletic participation or interest.

John C. Nettleton expects to receive his B.S.in chemical engineering from Villanova University in June 1957. He has served as president of the student chapter of A.I.Ch.E., and as secretary of Phi
Kappa Phi fraternity. John is now wondering about the pros and
cons of advanced study in his field.

Robert J. BuCh, M.S., Ch.E., came

to the Engineering Development Section of Du Pont's Grasselli Research Division from
the University of Louisville four years ago. Since then, he has
engaged in many kinds of chemical engineering work,from pilotplant operation to evaluation of the potential of proposed research programs. Within the last year, Bob has taken the responsibility of procuring B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. technical graduates in all phases of chemistry and chemical engineering for the
Grasselli Research Division.

AN advanced degree would undoubtedly have a favorable
M effect in technical work, John, but let me enlarge on
that just a little. In your own field (and mine, too) a
higher degree is considered to be evidence of ability in
carrying out original research. It is therefore helpful in
obtaining work in research and development, where that
skill is definitely important. You might say that it gives a
man a head start in proving his ability in those areas.
It's less important in some other areas, though. For
example, in production or sales work ability for handling
human relationships is just as important for advancement
as technical competence. If an engineer is sold on production" work or sales, a graduate degree in marketing
or business administration might be more helpful to him
than advanced technical training in getting started.

But I've noticed this at Du Pont. Once-a man lands a
job in his chosen field and actually begins to work, his
subsequent advancement depends more on demonstrated
ability than on college degrees. That's true throughout
the entire company—in scientific work, administration,
or what not.
So an advanced degree is not a royal road to anything
at Du Pont, John. But when coupled with proven abilities, it is unquestionably helpful to a man in research and
development work. It often gets him off to a faster start.

Next 'Stormer Show
The Barnstormers will present

Will co-star as Duke Montec and

as Boze Hartzlinger and Dave
Hotchberg as Gramp Maple:
Wolf will be assisted by Dave
Hotchberg, vice president of the
Barnstormers, as assistant director, and by Dave Scribner, production manager of the Barnstormers, as technical director.
A December 6 dress rehearsal
in Shriver at 8:30 will be open
to all Hopkins students. Admission for the main performances
and the dress rehearsal is free.

According to Wolf, the story
is built around "an incident in a
roadside cafe, and involves escaped,criminals and many other
human interest characters."

parts, while Stuart Hanlein, Joe
Rivkin, Mike Reisman, Warren
Donahue and Ernest Boatman
will also appear, as will Walter
Darrow and Gene Coakley.

for the Barnstormers by participating in the production, while
six regular Barnstormers members will also act.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 16, 1956

Anthropoligist Straus Asks
'Is Man Overspecialized?'
"Will he (Man) go the way of
those other overspecialized and
now extinct animals whose remains populate the various strata
of the geological record?" challenged Dr. William L. Straus, Jr.,
Professor of physical anthropology, concluding this year's
first University Lecture held
Wednesday.
In this age of nuclear fission
it remains to be seen whether
Man will make use of his unique
cerebral endowment to retain and
further expand his inheritance,
particularly by developing his
societal relations to the point of
living in peace and harmony with
other members of his own species.
•
"On the other hand, our so-

What's doing...atPrattd WhitneyAiwa

called "most advanced" current
cultures exhibit such disquieting
features as over-mechanization,
robotis, and anti-intellectuallism, worship of mediocrity, and
breakdown of many fundamental
societal relationships. If these
features really indicate as some
people suspect, that certain parts
of Man's brain have become overspecialized at the expense of the
rest of his brain and the rest of
his body, will he go the .way of
those other overspecialized and
now extinct animals whose remains populate the various strata
of the geological record? The
challenge is his to meet and
conquer.
Dr. Straus developed evolution
as it related to man from the
stage when life on earth was
totally acquatic up to the present
stage. Commenting on Aristotle's
definition of man as "the rational animal", Straus said, "As for
rationality, the less said the better, for true rationality probably
was not a property of all the men
that have lived across the span
of geological time—nor, indeed,
sadly, of all present day Men,
despite their appellation, Homo
Sapiens, or 'wise man', an appellation conceived by their own
vanity."
He said that man's brain,
"Especially its highly developed
'association' or 'ideational' areas
—represents the greatest and
actually the only real peculiarity
of Man." He added that although
the hand was critical in the deevlopment of man, it was not the
all-important factor. "There is
not a single primary movement
that can be made by the human
hand that cannot be made by the
hand of an Old World monkey.
The 'ideational' or 'conceptual'
areas of the monkey's brain,
however, are but poorly developed
when compared with these areas
of the human brain. Thus the
monkey does not have the ideas
necessary to synthesize the primary manual movements into
the intricate series of coordinated movements required in such
activity as tool-making or the
like; nor does the monkey exhibit
any great degree of foresight."

may continue study to earn Master's degree
Ambitious young engineering graduates today
want to be in two places at the same time. They
want to be employed as quickly as possible, working daily at a/job that offers promise of a rewarding career. They also want to be in the classroom,
pursuing advanced studies they know to be so
essential to real professional achievement.
Recognizing the many significant benefits to be
gained by that two-fold ambition — benefits that
accrue both to the individuals, personally, and
to the company employing them — Pratt & Whitney Aircraft has developed an extensive graduate
fellowship program. Within easy commuting distance of P & W A facilities, working arrangements
have been established - with graduate schools at
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, University of

Connecticut, Trinity College, Yale University,
Northeastern University and New York University. Similar arrangements with several other universities are pending final approval.
At each school, the qualified Pratt & Whitney
Aircraft employee is able to take courses — within
specified areas — leading to a Master's degree.
A tuition-refund plan makes it possible for successful degree candidates to obtain this advanced education tuition-free.
In this era of advancing technology, the world's
foremost designer and builder of aircraft engines
has taken a far-reaching step to assure its engineers and scientists of the opportunity for personal growth ... growth that is so beneficial to
employee and company alike.

With Coach Lincoln Simon
very pessimistic about their
chances, the Blue Jay varsity
harriers travel to Gallaudet tomorrow to participate in the
Mason-Dixon Conference crosscountry championships.
Simon stated, "Two of o u r
men, Phil Scheiner, and Bill
Frack, are very dubious starters."
Scheiner is troubled with bad
ankles, while Frack, who has
been on and off the .injured list
all season, Ls also a doubtful
starter.
According to Simon, the two
bright spots in the rather gloomy
picture are Morris Jones and
Charlie Ginsberg. The Jay coach
hopes Jones will place in the
first ten in the M-D tourney,
while expecting Captain Ginsberg to come through with another good performance. Simon
also has hopes for a.reversal of
the loss to Loyola, as well as a
sixth place finish in the MasonDixon tourney.
Last Saturday the Jays defeated the Shoremen of Washington College as Morris Jones
paced both teams. Jones missed
the course record by six seconds
as he made several wrong turns
on the strange course.
Simon stated, "the Washington College win was a team victory with each man playing an
important and decisive role in
the triumph."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 16, 1956

Frosh Gridders Post Fourth Win
To Close Season Undefeated
By HAL STOLLER
Led by Quarterback Oz Gakcia
and end Bob Brannon, the freshman football team scored its
fourth straight victory and climaxed an undefeated season by
downing Western Maryland 27-6
last Friday.
The fledgling Jays tallied in
the first quarter on a 19 yard
Pass from Garcia to Brannon.
Rod Simonsen added the extra
Point to make it 7 to 1'. Hopkins
tallied twice in the second period, on a quarterback sneak by
Garcia, and then with time running out, Garcia heaved .a 37
Yard pass to Brannon who went
all the way for the touchdown.
This made the score at halftime,
Hopkins 20, Western Maryland 0.
Garcia Scores
Garcia scored again in t h e
third quarter as he scampered
60 yards for Hopkins' final TD.
Simonsen again added the extra point. The defensive line play
of ends Bob Brannon, and Paul
Grim, Tackles; Marc Williams
and Paul Winegrad, Guards;
Francis Daley, John Corcoran,
and John Archer, and center
Maberon Meadows, subbing for
the injured Ray Lanzi, held the
W. Md. offense in check until
the last few minutes of the game,
When they scored on a, quarterback sneak, making the final

score, Hopkins
Maryland 6.

26,

Western

Said Coach Scott, "It was an
entire team victory, and I am
especially pleased, since this is
my first undefeated football team
I've had since I've been here."
Tackle Paul Winegrad presented Coach Major Tracy Caine
with the game football in appreciation of his work. Major
Caine has been frosh line coach
and will be leaving for Germany
in the early spring on active
duty.

Frosh Statistics
On the overall season, Simonsen, Phebus, and Garcia led the
rushing with averages of 7.1, 5.4,
and 4.6 yards per carry. Garcia
passed for 7 touchdowns out of
the 15 scored, and Simonsen
booted 11 out of 15 extra points.
Russ Martin.son averaged 38.2
yards per punt, and Simonsen
and Brannon led the team's scoring with 41 and 30 points each,
followed by Phebus and Garcia
with 12 and Martinson with 6
points.

The fraternity football championship was decided last week
In a pair of big games on Wednesday and Thursday. Beta won
for the fourth straight year. For
the League title and the right
to play Beta for the championhsip, Phi Gam and DU played
to a 6-6 tie. This draw sent Phi
Gam into the final rpund with
a 4-0-1 record, while DU's record was 3-0-2. In the championship game, Beta trounced Phi
Gam 24-6. Dick Allen threw a
pair of touchdown passes to Tony
Salem and Bob Williams, and intercepted a pass to run for a
third touchdown. Salem ran back
a punt the length of the field for
the other Beta 6-pointer. Billy
Morrill flipped a short pass to
Harry Nice for the Gam tally.
Pete Hubbard licked Art Brittingham in straight sets to cop
the Independent Tennis Crown
in the freshman dominated tourney, and Charley Sample beat
Herb Butler in the finals of the
Independent badminton tournament.
In the independent football
ranks, the 69ers edged the Newman Club 12-8 as Bruce Lynn
whipped two passes to Dean
Bangor for the victor's scores.
The Rowland Ghosts beat the
Vet's Club 24-6 in the other independent game.
